TITLE.P: Transfer system inside a dry dilution refrigerator

SHORT_DESCR.P: We wish to order two copies of a transfer system inside a Leiden Cryogenics dry dilution refrigerator. We found a company willing and able to design, develop and fabricate such a system. This company is BWI BV. in Leiden, the Netherlands.

Based on the requirements and market research we believe that BWI BV is the only company able and willing to design, develop and fabricate the transfer system and that a negotiated procedure is justified. Please see the attached memo for a description of the goal and requirements of the transfer probe.

This publication is done to indication of our intention to award the contract based on the negotiated procedure. Other companies can make representations if they don't agree with our decision to use the negotiated procedure. Protests have to made within 20 days after publication by lodging summary proceedings at the Rechtbank Den Haag. Questions can be raised using the Question & Answer module on Negometrix.
We wish to order two copies of a transfer system inside a Leiden Cryogenics dry dilution refrigerator.
The systems consist of a transfer system for a range of scanning probe microscopes and a vibration isolation system that is part of the transfer system:
1. The first instrument to be transferred from room temperature to the low temperature stage is a Scanning Tunneling Microscope.
2. The system must be compatible with a sample cleaver.
3. Further future scanning probe microscopes that need to be transferred are a ‘magnetic resonance force microscope’ and a ‘fiber/tuning fork SPM’.
4. The transfer system must be able to transfer an SPM as well as just the tip (or the sample).

D_JUSTIFICATION.P: We wish to order two copies of a transfer system inside a Leiden Cryogenics dry dilution refrigerator. We found a company willing and able to design, develop and fabricate such a system. This company is BWI BV in Leiden, the Netherlands.

Based on the requirements and market research we believe that BWI BV is the only company able and willing to design, develop and fabricate the transfer system and that a negotiated procedure is justified.

The goals of the project are to interrogate quantum materials, devices for quantum computation and experiments that interrogate the foundations of quantum mechanics. To this end we perform scanning probe microscopies at extremely low temperatures. For the STM experiments we strive for an effective electron temperatures of 10mK while for the force measurements in magnetic resonance microscopy we strive for cantilever temperatures down to 2 mK. Both microscopies require extremely good vibration isolation. For the magnetic resonance force microscopy technique the vibration isolation at acoustic frequencies needs to be state of the art. This vibration requirement is especially hard to reach in combination with the required low temperatures.
The systems consist of a transfer system for a range of scanning probe microscopes and a vibration isolation system that is part of the transfer system:
1. The first instrument to be transferred from room temperature to the low temperature stage is a Scanning Tunneling Microscope.
2. The system must be compatible with a sample cleaver.
3. Further future scanning probe microscopes that need to be transferred are a ‘magnetic resonance force microscope’ and a ‘fiber/tuning fork SPM’.
4. The transfer system must be able to transfer an SPM as well as just the tip (or the sample).
See document on Negometrix for further information.

TITLE.P: Transfer system inside a Leiden Cryogenics dry dilution refrigerator

INFO_ADD.P: This publication is to indicate our intent to award the contract. Representations can be made within 20 days after this publication. If no representations are received, the contract will be awarded.
